content:
Hi all,

Just for fun, I played with chain reactions in lean4 code and here's a little “what-if” game with the Riemann zeta function: what if a zero accidentally wandered off the critical line?
Using Mathlib’s beautiful riemannZeta, I formalized a toy cascade where one off-critical zero hypothetically spawns more via the functional equation and derivative identities—purely as an abstract chain reaction, of course.

As a result I got a harmless exploration of how classical analytic folklore (Selberg, Levinson–Montgomery) might look in Lean.
Code lives here: lean-cascade/

No breakthroughs here (I'm a little too old and use this game to teach kids) but perhaps it can lay down in one's real prove of that stuff one day: so many young people around.

If any brave souls have already ventured into the wilds of the argument principle, explicit formulas, or derivative scarcity results (looking at you, future Littlewood formalizers!), I’d be deeply grateful for pointers—or even better, collaboration! Right now those pieces live as sorry-lemmas, patiently waiting for someone who actually knows how to count zeros without breaking the type system :sweat_smile:
copying the contents of your files Cascade/Analytic.lean and Cascade/CascadeZeta.lean to the online editor cause import errors because you're importing the folders instead of the files
